thread.title: Northwestern soccer's Haley Hebelka returns, lifts Tigers into Colonial League final
thread.title_full: Northwestern soccer's Haley Hebelka returns, lifts Tigers into Colonial League final

title: Northwestern soccer's Haley Hebelka returns, lifts Tigers into Colonial League final
text:
Complete Box Score Â» 
During Northwestern girls soccer team's two-game losing streak near the end of the regular season, Tigers senior defender Haley Hebelka was out with an injury. 
She was back on the field on Tuesday night at Northern Lehigh High School and it certainly helped the Tigers. 
In fact, her return from injury led Northwestern to an upset of top-seeded Saucon Valley and into the Colonial League final. 
Hebelka scored off a corner kick with 1:25 remaining in the first half to lift the fourth-seeded Tigers to a 1-0 win over the Panthers. 
"It's nice to have that senior leadership back on the field," Northwestern coach Kelly Bleam said. "She's huge. The senior leadership is one thing. She's rock solid as a defender and she comes forward well. She shoots the ball well. Hals does a lot of things well. And last year, the whole season we were without her. So I'm thrilled for her that she's had the opportunity to come back from the minor injury of this season and of course come away with the winning goal." 
Tigers freshman midfielder Maggie Motolese delivered the corner kick, which was gathered by Hebelka, who then deposited it into the back of the net. Haley Hebelka (Josh Folck | For lehighvalleylive.com) 
"A beautiful cross from the corner," Hebelka said. "I just went for it and crashed the net." 
Finding the back of the net isn't something Hebelka is used to. 
"My second goal of my career. I don't score too often," Hebelka said. 
Saucon Valley, which didn't lose a league game all season and hasn't lost since its first game on Sept. 4, was without leading scorer Lauren Binn and key defender Ashleigh Nagy. They both tore ACLs last week. 
The Tigers took advantage of the the short-handed Panthers, controlling possession much of the game, especially in the first half. 
"Saucon Valley is like the best team in the Colonial League right now and to get a win over them is like the best feeling in the world," Hebelka said. 
"We really focused on defending and defending as a team," Hebelka added. "We wanted to just keep them from shooting and using their strengths." 
Sophomore goalkeeper McKenna Amey made three saves to preserve the Tigers' shutout. 
"That was such an amazing win," Amey said. "We have been practicing so hard, working on everything. We just did everything perfectly tonight. And we came out and we wanted to dominate and we did. We did amazing." 
Along with Hebelka, Motolese returned from injury on Tuesday night, giving the Tigers a needed boost after they saw their struggles towards the end of the regular season. 
"It definitely helps to have almost our whole team back and healthy again and able to participate," Bleam said. "I think that having everybody healthy for the most part tonight really contributed to the heart and emotion of the team." 
The Tigers will go for their third straight league title on Thursday night against Southern Lehigh, a team they beat 4-1 on Oct. 5. 
"It feels amazing. I'm so grateful for my team and my coaches," Hebelka said. "We're just going to keep working on defending and trying to get our shots off and working as a team."
